start: ^The guard approaches you, recognizing that you have an interest in ancient religions.
^"Ah, I see you've been talking to the villagers about the old ways. Not many people appreciate the ancient gods anymore."
^Tell me more about the old rituals.
^Do you still practice any of these rituals?
^Why do you think fewer people go to church?
^What was the most important lesson you learned from those celebrations?

c-0: ^"Our ancestors believed that every tree, every stone had a spirit. Rituals to the sun, moon, and earth helped us maintain balance in the world."
c-1: ^"In secret, some of us do. It's hard to let go of traditions that have been passed down for centuries, even if most people turn to Christianity now."
^The guard looks at you with curiosity. "I heard you were asking about religion in the village. The churches have been around for a long time, but things have changed."
c-2: ^"When I was a child, everyone went to church every Sunday. But now, fewer people attend services. People are more focused on their daily lives."
c-3: ^"The world is changing quickly. With the rise of technology and the internet, people question old beliefs. Traditions aren't as strong as they used to be."
^The guard smiles warmly. "So, you've heard about our celebrations. I grew up with them, too. They were some of the happiest memories of my childhood."
c-4: ^"It was always the summer solstice. We danced around bonfires, sang songs, and stayed up all night to watch the sunrise. Those were magical times."
c-5: ^"The celebrations taught me that life is cyclical. Every season has its role, just as every person has their purpose. It helped me see my place in the world."

c-0: ^The guard nods. "It's rare to meet someone who's interested in the old ways. Perhaps there's still hope for the ancient beliefs."
^The guard shrugs. "Times are changing, but it's important to remember where we came from. Even if fewer people go to church, the traditions still matter."
^The guard smiles. "Our traditions may seem strange to outsiders, but they are what keep us connected to our land and our ancestors."

end: ^You leave the guard with a deeper understanding of the religious and cultural traditions in Latvia.
